text:
JULIAN BEINART: I
was just thinking,

we're talking about cities
and having problems.

How long have cities existed,
including the first set

of permanent settlements, say
Jericho, 8,000 Before Christ.

How many years is
that til today?
20,000 years?
What are we now?
AUDIENCE: 10,000.
JULIAN BEINART: 10,000 years.

It took 2.6 million
years for human beings

to develop a brain
large enough to think.

And we're talking
about 12,000 years,
which was nothing in time.

And we are expecting
perfect answers
to communal settlements.
So relax.
[LAUGHTER]

I say this because
I'm an architect

and I've taught design
studios endlessly.

We tend to idealize the world
and smooth the world round.

I remember when I worked for
The Image of the City's research
book with Kevin Lynch.

K. Jerry Keppish,
his compatriot,

asked me to take a walk down
Washington Street on a busy day

and just note all the
things that I saw.

I made this tabulation
of all the things

that I saw, where the sun was
shining, what noise there was,

what signs there
were, and so on.

And I came up and
presented my work.

And said, this is such
an unbelievably confused
Washington Street.

I don't know how anybody
makes sense of it.

Because at that time, all urban
design was Viktor Gruen's work

and how to use modernism
to clean up conflict.

Shopping centers that
unified sign post control.

And here I was trying
to say the real world is
infinitely complex.

And yet, because we have 10 to
the 12 neurons in our brain,

each connecting to
5,000 other sites,

we have the electronic
system, which
can manage such complexity.

I think it's a message
worth remembering.

Maybe it will
become much clearer.

But I think working as you
do as an urban designer

in the midst of a
dialectic of opposites
is an intelligent place to be.
